_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Midwest Farmers Coop ¿ Brock, NE
P.O. Box 40
Elmwood, NE  68349

Risk Management Plan ¿ EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

Facility Policy:

The management and employees operating each of our facilities are committed to the prevention of any accidental release of hazardous material transported or stored on our locations. In the event an accidental release should occur, we are prepared to work with our Local Fire Company(s), Emergency Response Personnel, and other appropriate authorities deemed applicable to the specific incident. 

Facility Information:

The primary activity of our company is NAICS code 424510, ¿establishments primarily engaged in operating country or terminal grain elevators¿. However, we are also engaged in providing ¿agricultural inputs¿ that include the receiving, storage and reloading of anhydrous ammonia for delivery to farmers in our area. The NAICS code we feel is most applicable to this activity is 493130, ¿farm product warehousing and storage¿. 

Anhydrous ammonia is received, stored, and distributed for direct application to farm fields during the early spring and fall months. During the balance of the year little if any product transfer occurs. The facility is also operated on an ¿as needed¿ basis with staff present only during the receiving and reloading process. Our facilities have adequate lighting and are inspected at various times of day and night. 

Worst Case Scenario:

The maximum quantity released and the distance to endpoint calculations have been shared with the appropriate emergency planning and response agencies. Possible public and environmental receptors with the area have been provided to the Nemaha County LEPC for their consideration. 

Alternate Case Scenario:

This facility is new and there has not been an actual release of anhydrous ammonia on which to base this scenario. We decided to use a transfer hose rupture incident for this scenario and the quantity released and the distance to endpoint calculations have been shared with the a

ppropriate emergency planning and response agencies. 

Accidental Release Program and Planning:

Our anhydrous ammonia accidental release program is based on guidelines found in the ANSI Standard K61.1, ¿Safety Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia; and the U.S. OSHA Standard 29 CFR 1910.111, ¿Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia¿. We conduct annual employee training on the safe handling, transportation and distribution of anhydrous ammonia and have installed safety equipment including but not limited to: Excess flow valves. Emergency valves, Emergency couplers at transfer points, Protection from vehicular damage for the storage tank and attached piping, and Security locking mechanisms to prevent vandalism when the site is unattended. We have developed an Emergency Action Plan for employees, customers, and visitor protection. This plan initiates evacuation, emergency medical care, contacts for assistance, etc. for this anhydrous ammonia facility and the employees that staff it. 

Additional Information:

For additional information, response to questions,  or comments please contact:

Safety Department	at	(402) 227-2715
